Questions.Question: According to the lesson, in BookShelf's architecture, the BookRepository interface is an example of what type of port?
Questions.Explanation: BookRepository is a driven (outbound) port - an interface that defines what BookShelf needs from the outside world (data persistence). The application calls this port to store and retrieve books.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, driving ports are interfaces that the application calls to request services from the outside world.
Questions.Explanation: Driving (inbound) ports are interfaces that the OUTSIDE WORLD calls to interact with the application. Driven (outbound) ports are what the application calls. The lesson explains: 'Driving Ports define what your application offers to the world.'

Questions.Question: According to the BookShelf port examples, which of the following are DRIVEN ports? Select ALL that apply.
Questions.Explanation: BookRepository and NotificationSender are driven ports - they define what BookShelf NEEDS from external systems (database, email). BookService and UserService are driving ports - what BookShelf OFFERS to the outside world.

Questions.Question: According to the lesson, ports are _______ that define contracts between your application and the outside world.
Questions.Explanation: The lesson defines ports as interfaces - technology-agnostic contracts. They don't specify HOW something is done, only WHAT operations are available.
